body_html:
@bhack The XLA compiler is open-source, and everyone is welcome to use it and improve it. We mean it! Even though it lives in the Tensorflow repository, XLA is quite modular and does not depend on more than a few low level C++ utility libraries from Tensorflow. You can build and use XLA without the rest of Tensorflow right now if you like. It's still early days, and we are open to ideas on how to evolve XLA.

We haven't publicized this widely yet, but there is a new mailing list for XLA development:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/xla-dev
This sort of open-ended discussion might be better on that list rather than in a Github issue.

We haven't publicized this widely yet, but there is a new mailing list for XLA development:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/xla-dev
This sort of open-ended discussion might be better on that list rather than in a Github issue.
body:
@bhack The XLA compiler is open-source, and everyone is welcome to use it and improve it. We mean it! Even though it lives in the Tensorflow repository, XLA is quite modular and does not depend on more than a few low level C++ utility libraries from Tensorflow. You can build and use XLA without the rest of Tensorflow right now if you like. It's still early days, and we are open to ideas on how to evolve XLA.

We haven't publicized this widely yet, but there is a new mailing list for XLA development:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/xla-dev
This sort of open-ended discussion might be better on that list rather than in a Github issue.
